examples: It's childish and inane to say the least.
First, the linked content is trivial and inane.
The illustration seems gratuitous and a little inane.
Both the fish and geyser agruments are inane.
Most of the listed events are unimmportant or inane.
Not too mention the race for the record is inane.
The content of this paragraph is actually quite inane.
This is either the most inane article or the most pure and essential.
They range from the simple to the complex, from inane to brilliant.
It's nice to see the push for the inclusion of the inane to be slowing down.

name: syllogism

definitions.noun: (nou) deductive reasoning in which a conclusion is derived from two premises

examples: The rule of inference is a disjunctive syllogism.
The present template is a breach of syllogism.
It's the syllogism of the simple minded.
But you forget the implied syllogism in the proposition.
Should the syllogism method of debate be included

The syllogism is derived from the 1905 paper.
In philosophy, we call the idea hypothetical syllogism.
The disputant sets out to break down the dialectical syllogism.
Someone has misunderstood the implications of a valid syllogism.

name: fortuitous

definitions.adjective:
(adj) having no cause or apparent cause
(adj) occurring by happy chance

examples: The arrival of the diesels proved to be fortuitous.
The change proved to be fortuitous.
The collapse of the case against her was fortuitous.
The circumstances surrounding the recording were fortuitous.
This fact would prove fortuitous in the symphony's ultimate fate.

name: sardonic

definitions.adjective: (adj) disdainfully or ironically humorous; scornful and mocking- Frank Schoenberner- Irwin Edman

examples: O'Casey's treatment of the myth is generally viewed as ironic or sardonic.
She seemed quite sardonic.
Long live Sir Stephen the Sardonic
Any humor that the character shows is sardonic and cruel.

He made a mockery of the serious and had a sardonic vulgar wit.
My sardonic reply to that threat was to throw his threat back in his face.

name: exiguous

definitions.adjective: (adj) extremely scanty

examples: There remained an exiguous fighter force by day and night .
Parking is exiguous; the site is accessible from the roadside by footpaths.
They had an exiguous time to complete the project only four weeks in studio.

name: symbiotic

definitions.adjective: (adj) used of organisms (especially of different species) living together but not necessarily in a relation beneficial to each

examples: It is sort of an opposite to the symbiotic relationship.

name: capricious

definitions.adjective:
(adj) changeable
(adj) determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason

examples: She is capricious and a coquette.

name: tautological

The villian vitiated their boss.
Such communication shall not vitiate their input.
But that does not vitiate the worth of the entire book.
An edit looks to vitiate the policy itself.
Please do not discuss anything that'll vitiate the atmosphere.
I see no reason to vitiate the article by removing the summarized information.
This vitiates any attempt to evaluate wealth on a large scale basis.
Does the binary nature of the choice somehow vitiate his choice to say yes
Doesn't that vitiate the argument that the mutation rate is too low in nature

name: acerbic

definitions.adjective:
(adj) sour or bitter in taste
(adj) harsh or corrosive in tone

examples: It is a combination of acerbic and cerberus.
Weaver was the acerbic manager of the Orioles.
He felt acerbity afterwards.
She can handle the taste of acerbity.
The writing is often characterized by acerbity and quarrelsomeness.
It was an acerbic critique of book reviewing practices.
Salty water helps to reduce acerbity.
He does not like the taste of acerbity.
John Major showed a traditional British acerbity.
Some unripened fruits have the taste of acerbity.

name: concatenation

definitions.noun:
(nou) the state of being linked together as in a chain; union in a linked series
(nou) the linking together of a consecutive series of symbols or events or ideas etc
(nou) a series of things depending on each other as if linked together
(nou) the act of linking together as in a series or chain

examples: Concatenate them into one file.
The paragraph is a concatenation of these four fields.
Our job is to summarize and concatenate.
Concatenation may be thought of as the inverse of partitioning.
Cuts can nest and concatenate at will, but must never intersect.
Output of the function is concatenation of the left and right halves.
Terms concatenate combinators and lower case letters.
The output is the concatenation of the final left and right halves.
A tar file is the concatenation of one or more files.
Concatenate them into one file after by doing.

relations.broad_terms: series, link, joining, connexion, connection, connectedness

name: superfluous

definitions.adjective:
(adj) serving no useful purpose; having no excuse for being
(adj) more than is needed, desired, or required

examples: The addition of the country name is superfluous.
Is the image genuinely superfluous to the article
The nickname is superfluous in the opening paragraph.
Anything else is just superfluity.
It is as if the structure of the food is superfluous.
It's the rest of the material that seemed superfluous.
Most of the rest was superfluous.
Also, the year seems superfluous in the title.
Here's hoping to the quick eradication of superfluity
Most of the story becomes dross and superfluous.

relations.synonyms: excessive, extraneous, extra, pleonastic, supernumerary, surplus, unnecessary, extravagant

name: pecuniary

definitions.adjective: (adj) relating to or involving money

examples: They impose a pecuniary punishment or mulct.
They then will not be liable for any pecuniary dues.
He was under pecuniary obligation to him.
But this mark of honour was not accompanied by any pecuniary emolument.
There are no pecuniary penalties available for a breach of section 52.
To do such a thing to obtain a licence is pecuniary.
This is done by various insinuation about pecuniary motivations and otherwise.
With an equally niggardly hand are pecuniary grants and pensions distributed.
The pecuniary difficulties of the Institution had become very great.
The requirement of pecuniary loss can be shown in a number of ways.

name: cadre

definitions.noun:
(nou) a small unit serving as part of or as the nucleus of a larger political movement
(nou) a nucleus of military personnel capable of expansion

examples: He was responsible to train the cadre to be sent to operate in the Northeast.
This have not affected the competence of the officer cadre.
The rest was done by the cadres of the ruling party.
She is regarded as one of the oldest women cadre of the outfit.
The officers are included in the state cadre of civil service officers.
He was said to be one of the hardcore cadre of the outfit.
Cadre started with the simple mission of protecting the city.
He belongs to the Kerala cadre of 1972 batch of the IAS.
Kamte was part of the 1989 batch of the IPS of the Maharashtra cadre.
The participation of Muslims in the professional and managerial cadre is low.

name: pejorative

definitions.adjective: (adj) expressing disapproval

examples: That is the meaning of pejorative.
As the second sentence states, the term is pejorative.
The phrase is a pejorative term in the United States.
The links in that section all support the pejorative definition.
It's enough to describe the crime without the pejorative label.
The article also describes the term as prejudicial and pejorative.
Usage of the term ranges from the affectionate to the pejorative.
The term ultramontane has pejorative connotations in English.
I deprecate the pejorative language used in the nomination.
It's the possibly pejorative nature of the word to the people it's describing.
